pr_title: Fix a few flakey tests, add more context when logging transport messages

timeline.bodyText: This information has been useful to me when debugging these flakey tests, and I suspect customer's will appreciate this too
timeline.author: timtay-microsoft

replies.bodyText: This will log if a message is a twin subscription message, method subscription message, etc.
replies.author: timtay-microsoft

timeline.bodyText: The commit message explains this further, but Android SDKs return -1 when inputStream.read(...) reads no bytes. JDKs return 0 though. For consistency between JDK and android SDK, we shouldn't use this return value
timeline.author: timtay-microsoft

timeline.bodyText: This status class was used to simplify twin callbacks, but it hid useful information for failure cases. Knowing why a callback fired back with an unsuccessful state is important to log when the test fails
timeline.author: timtay-microsoft

timeline.bodyText: only return the newly created property
timeline.author: timtay-microsoft
timtay-microsoft

replies.author: timtay-microsoft
timtay-microsoft

timeline.bodyText: Again, only send the reported properties that belong to this thread. See above for why
timeline.author: timtay-microsoft

timeline.message:
fix(e2e): fix flakey reported properties tests

Many reported property tests made the mistake of sending reported property updates with updated properties and properties that were not yet updated. As a result, the ordering that IoT Hub handled these messages determined if the test would pass or not. In effect, we would lose reported property updates because one update would accidentally overwrite another sometimes

refactor(iot-dev): Add additional logging context for transport messages

Logs should include the type of transport message (subscribe to twin request, subscribe to twin response, etc.) since that makes logs easier to read

fix(e2e): Fix android file upload test failures

android SDK returns -1 when inputStream.read(...) reads no bytes, but JDKs return 0. As a result, android would fail the file upload tests where the file had 0 bytes.

fix(e2e): Fix android file upload test failures

android SDK returns -1 when inputStream.read(...) reads no bytes, but JDKs return 0. As a result, android would fail the file upload tests where the file had 0 bytes.

timeline.bodyText: how is this going to affect the callback? is this considered a breaking change?
timeline.author: azabbasi

replies.bodyText: This is in the test code, so it isn't a breaking change, no
replies.author: timtay-microsoft

replies.bodyText: ah, the file path threw me off
replies.author: azabbasi

timeline.bodyText: this method is no longer doing what its name implies does it? it's creating and returning a new set
timeline.author: azabbasi

replies.bodyText: It still does what it says. It only returns the property that was updated, but that returned property did already exist
replies.author: timtay-microsoft

replies.bodyText: By the way, this and other methods always return Set even when only one property is in the set. The reason for this is so that the test method can use this returned value directly when calling "sendReportedProperties(Set)" instead of building the set after calling this method
replies.author: timtay-microsoft

replies.bodyText: I see, so it updates the existing and also returns a new set as a return value. fair.
replies.author: azabbasi
